question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Proof::generate()] [Point group selection] Does unsafe_random_points_group() generate points in the correct group (G2)? Can it accidentally generate points in G1 or invalid subgroups, breaking pairing-based proof verification? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Proof::generate()] [Scalar field mismatch] Can the scalar field used in z differ from the scalar field of the pairing E, causing field element operations to produce incorrect results and corrupt DKG outputs? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Proof::generate()] [Tuple homomorphism binding] Does the TupleCodomainShape properly bind first_proof_item_inner to the second component? Can misalignment between these components create proofs that pass structural checks but fail cryptographic verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Proof::generate()] [Point at infinity] Can unsafe_random_points_group() return the point at infinity (identity element)? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Proof::generate()] [Subgroup check bypass] Are the randomly generated points checked to be in the correct prime-order subgroup? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Proof::generate()] [Pairing compatibility] Does the generated proof structure maintain pairing compatibility where e(g1, g2) operations will succeed? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Homomorphism::new()] [Parameter validation] Are lagr_g1, xi_1, pp, and eks validated for correctness before use? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Homomorphism::new()] [Lagrange basis corruption] Can an attacker provide lagr_g1 with duplicate or zero points, breaking the Lagrange interpolation basis and allowing them to create invalid shares that appear valid? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Homomorphism::new()] [Xi commitment manipulation] Can xi_1 be set to the point at infinity or an invalid curve point, causing the HKZG commitment to be trivial and breakable by brute force? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Homomorphism::new()] [Lifetime safety] The function takes multiple lifetime 'a references - can these references be invalidated during proof generation/verification, causing use-after-free vulnerabilities and memory corruption? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/hkzg_chunked_elgamal_commit.rs] [Function: Homomorphism::new()] [Projection function security] The projection closure that unchunks chunks - can it be exploited if chunked_plaintexts have irregular chunk sizes, causing out-of-bounds reads or incorrect scalar reconstruction?
